author: catwith1hat
content:
Did EIP-7251 unintentionally lower slashing penalties for 32 ETH validators from 1 ETH to 0.0078125 ETH?

[The Electra update](https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/blob/dev/specs/electra/beacon-chain.md#rewards-and-penalties) defines `MIN_SLASHING_PENALTY_QUOTIENT_ELECTRA = 4,096`  which was `MIN_SLASHING_PENALTY_QUOTIENT_BELLATRIX = 32` before. I can't see the redefinition of [`slash_validator`](https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/blob/dev/specs/electra/beacon-chain.md#modified-slash_validator) make a distinction between big/small validator. It's all just two lines:
```
    slashing_penalty = validator.effective_balance // MIN_SLASHING_PENALTY_QUOTIENT_ELECTRA
    decrease_balance(state, slashed_index, slashing_penalty)
```
And this math changes from 32/32 (=1) to 32/4096 (=0.0078125). 

While EIP-7251 argues lowering the min slash penalty quotient is an incentive to switch to a large validator, I can't see at all how this translates to the actual Python in the consensus-spec. I would argue that it is actually a disincentive to consolidate.

Am I missing something?
